questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is admitted to the ICU after experiencing a cardiac arrest. CT imaging is given below. What is this radiological finding called?
questions.explanation:
Global cerebral hypoperfusion

Epidemiology
  • Older children: drowning and asphyxiation.
  • Adults: cardiac arrest or cerebrovascular disease, leading to secondary hypoxemia or hypoperfusion.

Clinical Presentation
  • Patients typically present after an acute event (e.g., near-drowning, asphyxia, cardiac/respiratory arrest).

Pathology
  • Severe global hypoxic-ischemic injury
  • Grey matter is particularly vulnerable to injury because of its high metabolic demands for oxygen and glucose, along with its abundance of postsynaptic glutamate receptors, which make it more prone to excitotoxicity from excessive glutamate stimulation.

Radiological findings
  • Diffuse edema with effacement of CSF-containing spaces

 

Reversal Sign: (Option A ruled out)

  • Involves the reversal of normal CT attenuation between grey and white matter.
  • Linked to distension of deep medullary veins due to partial venous outflow obstruction from elevated intracranial pressure.
  • White matter appears of higher attenuation than grey matter.

White Cerebellum Sign: (Option B ruled out)

  • Seen with diffuse edema and hypoattenuation of cerebral hemispheres, sparing the cerebellum and brainstem.
  • Makes the cerebellum and brainstem appear hyperattenuated relative to cerebral hemispheres.
  • Pseudo subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option C): caused by cerebral edema, reduced parenchymal attenuation, swelling, and engorged superficial venous structures, leading to the subarachnoid space appearing hyperdense, mimicking a hemorrhage.
  • Both the reversal sign and the white cerebellum sign are associated with severe brain injury and poor neurological outcomes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, vomiting, and right-sided weakness. Additionally, he exhibits altered sensorimotor integration and difficulty with voluntary movement control. His blood pressure is recorded at 190/110 mmHg. A CT scan of the head is performed with findings given below Based on the findings, Which artery is most likely involved in this case?

A 65-year-old patient presents with bilateral thalamic and basal ganglia symptoms, including motor weakness and sensory disturbances. MRI reveals bilateral infarcts in these regions. Which type of venous thrombosis is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Venous Anatomy

Cerebral veins are categorized into external (superficial) and internal veins, draining the outer and inner regions of the cerebral hemisphere.

External Cerebral Veins
  • Superior Cerebral Veins: Typically 8 to 12 in number, these veins drain the upper parts of the hemisphere, entering the superior sagittal sinus after piercing the arachnoid mater.
  • Middle Cerebral Veins: Comprising four veins (two superficial and two deep), these veins drain the lateral sulcus, connecting to the cavernous sinus, superior sagittal sinus (Trolard), and transverse sinus (Labbe). The deep veins merge with the anterior cerebral vein to form the basal vein.
  • Inferior Cerebral Veins: Numerous smaller veins that drain the inferior surfaces of the hemisphere into nearby dural venous sinuses.

Additional Veins
  • Anterior Cerebral Vein: Drains parts of the medial surface alongside the anterior cerebral artery.
  • Basal Vein (of Rosenthal): Formed by the anterior cerebral, deep middle cerebral, and striate veins, this vein runs around the midbrain and drains into the great cerebral vein (of Galen), receiving tributaries from various brain structures.

Internal Cerebral Veins
  • Located on either side of the midline in the tela choroidea of the 3rd ventricle.
  • Formed at the interventricular foramen (of Monro) by the thalamostriate, septal, and choroidal veins.
  • Drain specific brain regions:
    • Thalamostriate (thalamus and basal ganglia)
    • Septal (septum pellucidum)
    • Choroidal (choroid plexus).
  • Unite beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum to form the great cerebral vein.

Great Cerebral Vein of Galen
  • A single vein (about 2 cm long) formed by the internal cerebral veins.
  • Receives basal veins and joins the inferior sagittal sinus to form the straight sinus.
  • Tributaries include:
    • Internal cerebral veins
    • Basal veins
    • Veins from the colliculi (tectum of the midbrain)
    • Veins from the cerebellum and adjacent occipital lobes

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a severe headache that started 2 days ago. She reports associated symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and a few episodes of seizure. A history of recent oral contraceptive use is present. On examination, she has a mild altered mental status but no focal deficits. A CECT is given below. What specific sign on CT is characteristic of this diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Central venous sinus thrombosis

 
  • CVT should be suspected in patients presenting with headaches, seizures, or encephalopathy.
  • Can occur in superficial or deep dural venous sinuses, affecting either isolated veins or as part of broader venous sinus thrombosis.
  • Factors like intracranial infections, trauma, dehydration, pregnancy, oral contraceptives, smoking, and vasculitis (e.g., Behçet disease) can trigger CVT. If absent, a thrombophilia screening is necessary.

CT Findings:

  • The empty delta sign, visible in contrast-enhanced CT scans, indicates dural venous sinus thrombosis in the superior sagittal sinus as a triangular filling defect outlined by contrast, representing a thrombus. (Option A)
  • The dense vein sign, a hyperdense vessel sign indicating hyperattenuating thrombus due to acute venous thrombosis, is found in cortical veins or dural venous sinuses. (Option D)

MRI Findings:

  • Loss of normal flow void; thrombosed vessels may appear hyperintense on T1 and T2 sequences. Very acute thrombus can be hypointense on T2, mimicking flow voids. Additionally, slow flow can also result in loss of the flow void.
  • MR venography (MRV) shows a loss of flow signal or irregularity, indicating a thrombus.
  • SWI (Susceptibility Weighted Imaging) can highlight thrombosed veins and detect acute hemorrhage.

Empty theca sign (Option B)

Empty sella sign (Option C)

  • The empty thecal sac sign occurs when the thecal sac appears empty on lumbar spine MRI, particularly on T2-weighted images.
  • It is seen in Adhesive arachnoiditis.

  • It occurs when the pituitary gland is shrunken or absent, with CSF filling the sella turcica.
  • Seen in idiopathic intracranial hypertension & Sheehan's syndrome

questions.text: A 75-year-old female with a history of stroke presents for follow-up imaging 6 months after an acute right middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarct. CT head is taken and is shown below. Which of the following imaging findings is most characteristic in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: T2 hypointensity in the ipsilateral corticospinal tract

options.label: B
options.text: High signal intensity on DWI and low signal on ADC

options.label: C
options.text: Enlarged sulci and ventricles with CSF-like signal intensity

options.label: D
options.text: Ipsilateral cerebellar volume loss due to large MCA infarcts

questions.correct_answer: C. Enlarged sulci and ventricles with CSF-like signal intensity

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents with left-sided weakness and speech difficulty for 8 hours. NCCT shows no hemorrhage, and CTAngiography reveals a proximal MCA occlusion. DWI shows a large infarct volume (>70 ml). According to the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Acute Stroke Imaging Algorithm, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Continue with tPA infusion and monitor

options.label: C
options.text: Consider perfusion imaging with CT or MRI

questions.correct_answer: C. Consider perfusion imaging with CT or MRI
questions.explanation:
Radiological Findings
CT Scan
  • Investigation of choice.
  • Characterized by cytotoxic edema, leading to significant but subtle changes in imaging.
  • This condition represents intracellular edema, which causes:
    • Loss of gray matter/white matter differentiation.
    • Effacement of cortical sulci.
  • Early ischemic lesion hypodensity on CT is the hallmark of acute brain infarction, indicating irreversible tissue damage and continual net water uptake.

  • Wedge shaped acute infarct.

  • A thrombus in the proximal middle cerebral artery (MCA) may be visible during the acute phase.
  • The thrombus appears as hyperattenuation on the CT scan.
  • Objectives of Non-Enhanced Cranial CT in Acute Stroke:
    • Exclude hemorrhage to allow aspirin therapy.
    • Exclude alternative causes of neurological deficit.
    • Assess infarct volume and calculate ASPECTS (Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score).
    • Detecting a hyperdense vessel.
    • Confirm infarct matches the clinical timeline and is not subacute.
Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI)
  • Has high sensitivity and specificity, detecting parenchymal hyperintensity as early as 5 minutes after infarction onset.
  • Determines area of penumbra.
  • DWI must be interpreted with an apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map.
  • Restricted diffusion in acute infarct appears bright on DWI and dark on the ADC map.
  • In rare cases, DWI-positive areas may not progress to infarction after early recanalization treatments (IV agents or mechanical thrombectomy).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden right-sided weakness and speech difficulty, starting 1 hour ago. A non-contrast CT scan is performed and is shown below. Which of the following signs is marked (arrow) in this case?

A 75-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The emergency physician needs to determine the best initial imaging modality to assess for an acute ischemic stroke and potential hemorrhage. Which imaging technique should be performed first?
questions.explanation:
Non-Contrast CT (Option C)

CT Angiography (Option B)

MRI (Option A)
  • Earliest Signs of Ischemic Stroke: loss of differentiation between gray and white matter.
  • Loss of Insular Ribbon Sign: seen when the middle cerebral artery is involved, with the insula showing early changes.

  • Hyperdense Vessel Sign: In hyperacute strokes, the thrombus appears dense, causing hyperattenuation of the occluded segment of the MCA.
  • CT scan can also reveal whether there is bleeding in the brain or damage to brain cells resulting from a stroke.
  • Provides high-resolution imaging of the vascular tree from the aortic arch to intracranial vessels.
  • Allows for functional perfusion imaging and assessment of collaterals.
  • Earliest Signs of Ischemic Stroke: restricted diffusion on diffusion weighted imaging.
  • Is observed within a few minutes of arterial occlusion.
  • Can identify changes in brain tissue and damage to brain cells.
  • Uses:
    • Diagnosis of major stroke.
    • To identify a contraindication to treatment, like hemorrhage or large infarct.
    • To identify stroke mimic such as brain tumor.
  • Use:
    • Detection of large vessel occlusion (LVO).

   
  • Uses: 
    • Most sensitive technique for acute ischemic stroke detection.
    • Used in imaging diagnosis of minor stroke
    • Typically during follow-up.

Artery

Supply Site

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

Lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)

Frontal poles, superior surfaces, and all medial surfaces of both cerebral hemispheres, except the calcarine cortex.

Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)

Superior midbrain, portions of the posterior thalamus, the medial occipital lobes and the medial and inferior portions of the temporal lobe.

Anterior Choroidal Artery: Branch of Internal Carotid Artery (ICA)

Choroid plexus of the ipsilateral lateral ventricle and parts of the hippocampus, amygdala, uncus, internal capsule, basal ganglia.

Lenticulostriate Branches: Branch of MCA

Caudate nucleus, globus pallidus, putamen, and part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache and loss of consciousness. An MRI is performed shortly after the incident and shows a hyperintense lesion on T1-weighted images and a hypointense lesion on T2-weighted images, consistent with an acute hematoma. What would be the phase of blood in this condition?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion and headache. A CT scan of the brain is performed which shows as follows: The radiologist notes a characteristic appearance of increased spacing between the frontal lobes. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He presents with loss of consciousness, altered mental status, decerebrate posturing, and widespread cerebral edema. A CT scan returns normal. After intubation, which MRI sequence is preferred for evaluating the extent of his neurological injuries?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Location of Injury

Description

Prognosis

I

Gray matter and white matter interface

Involves the initial site of axonal injury.

Relatively better prognosis

II

Corpus callosum

Involves the critical structure connecting the two hemispheres. Suggests more severe disruption of axonal pathways.

Worse prognosis than Grade I

III

Brain stem

Involves the brain stem, which can significantly affect vital functions.

Associated with the worst prognosis

questions.text: Assertion (A): On CT scan, the bone cortex appears black, while on MRI, it appears white. Reason (R): The appearance of structures on CT and MRI depends on the density of tissues and the presence of hydrogen atoms.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, and Reason (R) is the correct explanation of Assertion (A).

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true, but Reason (R) is not the correct explanation of Assertion (A).

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion (A) is false, but Reason (R) is true.

options.label: D
options.text: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are false.

questions.correct_answer: C. Assertion (A) is false, but Reason (R) is true.
questions.explanation:
Feature

CT (Computed Tomography)

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

Principle

Based on differential absorption of X-rays by tissues (denser tissues absorb more X-rays)

Based on the alignment of hydrogen protons in tissues in response to a magnetic field and radiofrequency pulses

Imaging Time

Faster

Slower, can take 30 minutes to over an hour
Bone cortex appearance:

White (due to dense bone absorbing X-rays)

Dark (lacks hydrogen protons)

Applications

Best for: Acute bleeding, skull fractures, calcifications, hyperacute stroke

Emergency use: Ideal for emergencies due to speed

Best for: Soft tissue details, brain tumors, demyelinating diseases, subacute/chronic ischemia

Emergency use: Not typically used in emergencies (except for soft tissue analysis)

Detection of Acute Hemorrhage

Highly sensitive for detecting acute hemorrhage

Less sensitive for acute hemorrhage, but can be used after a few days

Evaluation of Edema

Limited sensitivity to subtle edema

Excellent for detecting edema and differentiating tissue types

Stroke Detection

Good for detecting stroke in hyperacute phase (hours)

Better for detecting ischemia in subacute and chronic stages (days to weeks)

Contrast Agent Used

Iodine-based contrast agents (risk of allergy or kidney issues)

Gadolinium-based contrast agents (caution in renal failure)

Aspect

NCCT

CECT

Non-Contrast MRI

CE-MRI (Contrast-Enhanced MRI)

Radiation Exposure

Uses ionizing radiation (X-rays)

Uses ionizing radiation (X-rays)

No radiation (uses magnetic fields)

No radiation (uses magnetic fields)

Contrast Agent

No contrast agent used

Iodine-based contrast agent used

No contrast agent used

Gadolinium-based contrast agent used

Soft Tissue Resolution

Lower compared to MRI, useful for detecting acute bleeds

Better soft tissue contrast than NCCT due to contrast enhancement

Excellent soft tissue resolution, ideal for detecting subtle changes

Excellent soft tissue resolution with better contrast for lesions

Applications

Acute stroke (to exclude hemorrhage), trauma, calcifications

Tumor detection, infections, vascular abnormalities

Stroke (subacute/chronic), demyelinating diseases, tumors (no contrast)

Tumors, infections, vascular lesions, better delineation of blood-brain barrier disruptions

Imaging Modality

Applications

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT)
  • Acute ischemic stroke (to exclude hemorrhage)
  • Intracranial hemorrhage
  • Head trauma (skull fractures, brain injury)
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Calcifications (tumors, infections)

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT)
  • Brain tumors (primary and metastatic)
  • Infections (abscesses, encephalitis)
  • Vascular abnormalities (aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations)
  • Venous sinus thrombosis

High-Resolution CT (HRCT)
  • Detailed evaluation of brain parenchyma and skull base
  • Assessment of bony structures (temporal bones, skull fractures)
  • Evaluation of small vessel calcifications

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a significant history of smoking presents with a sudden onset of a severe headache. He reports accompanying symptoms of palpitations, photophobia, and neck stiffness. On examination, signs of meningeal irritation are noted. The patient also has hyperflexible joints and mentions that his symptoms began after experiencing a minor jerk while in the car. A CT scan reveals specific findings given below. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Meningitis secondary to a bacterial infection

options.label: B
options.text: Cervical spine injury leading to meningeal irritation

options.label: C
options.text: Migraine with aura exacerbated by the minor jerk

questions.correct_answer: D. Rupture of a cerebral aneurysm
questions.explanation:
Definition

Presence of blood in the subarachnoid space, typically from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or trauma.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap headache")
  • Worst headache ever experienced by the patient.

Etiology
  • Traumatic: Head injuries causing bleeding in the subarachnoid space.
  • Non-Traumatic: Most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

Initial Imaging

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): First-line imaging for suspected SAH, effective in the acute setting.
Radiological Findings (NCCT)

Appearance of Blood: Hyperdense (white) compared to surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

 

Common Sites for Blood Accumulation:

  • Interhemispheric Fissure
  • Sylvian Fissure
  • Suprasellar Cistern
  • Perimesencephalic Cistern


Distinctive Shape: Blood may take on a pentagon or star shape, referred to as the "Star of Death."

Additional Investigations

CT Angiography: Visualizes potential aneurysms or vascular malformations; useful for rupture suspicion.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for diagnosing cerebral aneurysms; provides detailed vascular images and therapeutic options (e.g., endovascular coiling).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents after a road traffic accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval. On examination, he has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 13 and exhibits signs of a head injury. A CT scan of the head was performed, and the image revealed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH)

Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH) (Option A)

Type of Hemorrhage

Arterial Hemorrhage

Venous Hemorrhage
Shape

Biconvex or lentiform

Crescent or sickle-shaped

Location

Limited by sutures; can cross the midline

Follows the brain surface; crosses sutures, does not cross midline

Cause

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (MMA)

Rupture of cortical bridging veins

Onset of Symptoms

Often presents with a lucid interval

Symptoms may develop gradually, often without a lucid interval

Force Required

Requires more force; associated with adjacent bony rupture

Can occur with trivial trauma

Midline Crossing

Can cross the midline

Does not cross the midline

Lucid Interval

Yes; patient appears normal before deterioration

No; deterioration may be more gradual

Clinical Signs

Symptoms may include headache, loss of consciousness, and focal neurological deficits

Symptoms may include headache, confusion, and potential focal deficits

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a head injury sustained during a fall. He is alert, opens his eyes to speech, follows commands, and is oriented but complains of a mild headache. On assessment, he opens his eyes spontaneously, is verbally coherent but slightly disoriented, and follows motor commands. There are no focal neurological deficits, bleeding disorders, seizures, or intoxication. Based on the clinical findings and his GCS score, what is the next appropriate step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Observation with repeat neurological assessment every 4 hours

questions.correct_answer: C. Observation with repeat neurological assessment every 4 hours
questions.explanation:
GCS Score

TBI Severity

13-15

Mild TBI

9-12

Moderate TBI

3-8

Severe TBI

questions.text: A patient comes with his MR angiography brain report to the clinic. Identify the marked artery in this image.
questions.explanation:
Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA)

There are various types of MR angiograms based on different principles and can be classified into non-contrast and contrast enhanced methods.

Non-contrast MRA

Contrast enhanced (CE) MRA

Time-of-flight (TOF) imaging:

  • It is the most prevalent method for Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) in clinical practice.

Phase-contrast MRA:

  • It is more sensitive for identifying slow blood flow and useful for imaging cerebral veins (MR venography or MRV).
  • Effective for detecting dural venous sinus thrombosis and venous stenoses.
  • MRA combined with gadolinium-based contrast agents is called contrast-enhanced (CE) MRA.
     
  • Excellent for quickly visualizing the carotid and vertebral arteries where a large field of view (FOV) is necessary.
     
  • Reduces artifacts caused by turbulent or slow flow.
     
  • Useful for assessing arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), aneurysms, and intracranial stenosis.
  • Two types are:
    • Elliptical-centric
    • Multiphase techniques

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the given image is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT for diagnosing stroke

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to resolve discrepancies in findings from noninvasive imaging

options.label: C
options.text: It diagnoses spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA results are negative

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used for embolization of AVMs and fistulas

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT for diagnosing stroke
questions.explanation:
Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA)

Clinical applications
  • Acute stroke protocols: CTA is a standard investigation alongside non-contrast CT and CT perfusion (CTP) for evaluating stroke.
  • It is used to detect dynamic contrast extravasation indicative of active hemorrhage.
  • It is highly sensitive (>90%) for intracranial aneurysms, particularly in subarachnoid hemorrhage cases.
  • It is also effective for assessing carotid artery stenosis, cervical artery dissection, and intracranial vascular stenosis

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Applications
  • Resolve discrepancies in findings from noninvasive imaging (CTA or MRA). (Option B)
  • Diagnosing spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA results are negative. (Option C)
  • Evaluate younger patients with intraparenchymal hemorrhage for underlying arteriovenous malformations (AVMs).
  • DSA supports a variety of endovascular treatments, including:
    • Clot retrieval for acute ischemic stroke
    • Treatment of brain aneurysms (coiling, stenting, flow diversion)
    • Embolization of AVMs and fistulas (Option D)
    • Tumor embolization and stenting of intracranial arterial stenoses
    • Intra-arterial therapies for vasospasm

questions.text: Match the following structures with their corresponding CT score. Structure CT score in HU a) Air 1) 0 b) Water 2) -1000 c) Grey Matter 3) 700 to 3000 d) Bone 4) 37 to 45
questions.explanation:
Structure

CT score in HU

a) Air

1) -1000

b) Water

2) 0

c) Grey Matter

3) 37 to 45

d) Bone

4) 700 to 3000

Structure

CT score (HU)

Air

-1000

Water

0

CSF

8 to 15

White matter

20 to 30

Blood

30 to 45

Grey matter

37 to 45

Contrast

100 to 300

Bone

700 (cancellous) to 3000 (inner and outer tables)

questions.text: A student is analyzing an MRI of the brain at the midbrain level. The examiner asks the student to identify the structure marked as “a”. What is this structure?
questions.explanation:
MRI BRAIN

CT BRAIN

  • This uses the alignment of hydrogen protons in tissues in response to a magnetic field and radiofrequency pulses.
  • The skull bone cortex appears black/dark in the MRI.

 
  • X-rays that penetrate the head or other parts of the body produce images based on tissue density and atomic number.
  • The bone cortex can be seen as a hyperintense (white) area.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with persistent headaches and cognitive decline. An MRI reveals a suspicious mass in the parietal lobe. To further characterize the mass, an MR spectroscopy (MRS) is performed which shows: Which of the following interpretations is most accurate regarding the metabolic changes observed in MR spectroscopy?

options.label: A
options.text: The elevated choline levels suggest high cellular turnover

options.label: B
options.text: The decreased NAA indicates significant neuronal viability

options.label: C
options.text: The absence of any metabolites in the spectrum indicates healthy brain tissue

options.label: D
options.text: Raised creatinine levels show low metabolic activity

questions.correct_answer: A. The elevated choline levels suggest high cellular turnover
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ MR Spectroscopy
  • ↳ MR Spectroscopy
  • ↳ MR Spectroscopy
  • ↳ MR Spectroscopy
  • ↳ It is a technique used to analyze metabolites in various tissues, including the brain, breast, and prostate done at 1.5 or 3T. Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues.
  • ↳ It is a technique used to analyze metabolites in various tissues, including the brain, breast, and prostate done at 1.5 or 3T. Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues.
  • ↳ It is a technique used to analyze metabolites in various tissues, including the brain, breast, and prostate done at 1.5 or 3T. Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues.

  • ↳ metabolites
  • ↳ brain, breast, and prostate
  • ↳ Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues.
  • ↳ lactate, lipids, and choline
  • ↳ Metabolite Markers N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) : indicates neuronal viability. (Option B) Choline : represents cell membrane composition and cellular turnover . Creatine : found in metabolically active tissues, serving as a reference. (Option D) Lipids : released during cell membrane damage. Lactate : signifies anaerobic metabolism. In a normal brain, these metabolites are present in the order: NAA > creatinine > choline. (Option C)

Creatine : found in metabolically active tissues, serving as a reference. (Option D) Lipids : released during cell membrane damage. Lactate : signifies anaerobic metabolism. In a normal brain, these metabolites are present in the order: NAA > creatinine > choline. (Option C)

Creatine : found in metabolically active tissues, serving as a reference. (Option D) Lipids : released during cell membrane damage. Lactate : signifies anaerobic metabolism. In a normal brain, these metabolites are present in the order: NAA > creatinine > choline. (Option C)

  • ↳ (Option B)

  • ↳ (Option C)

  • ↳ Clinical Applications
  • ↳ Clinical Applications
  • ↳ Clinical Applications
  • ↳ Choline is raised in malignancies. Lipids are raised in TB due to mycolipids of mycobacterium. MRS is used for assessing brain tumors, including: Grading of tumors. Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects. Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.
  • ↳ Choline is raised in malignancies. Lipids are raised in TB due to mycolipids of mycobacterium. MRS is used for assessing brain tumors, including: Grading of tumors. Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects. Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.
  • ↳ Choline is raised in malignancies.
  • ↳ Lipids are raised in TB due to mycolipids of mycobacterium.
  • ↳ MRS is used for assessing brain tumors, including: Grading of tumors. Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects. Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.
  • ↳ Grading of tumors. Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects. Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.
  • ↳ Grading of tumors.
  • ↳ Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects.
  • ↳ Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.

MR Spectroscopy
  • It is a technique used to analyze metabolites in various tissues, including the brain, breast, and prostate done at 1.5 or 3T.
  • Measures levels of lactate, lipids, and choline within a specific volume of tissues.

Metabolite Markers
  • N-acetyl aspartate (NAA): indicates neuronal viability. (Option B)
  • Choline: represents cell membrane composition and cellular turnover.
  • Creatine: found in metabolically active tissues, serving as a reference. (Option D)
  • Lipids: released during cell membrane damage.
  • Lactate: signifies anaerobic metabolism.
  • In a normal brain, these metabolites are present in the order: NAA > creatinine > choline. (Option C)

Clinical Applications
  • Choline is raised in malignancies.
  • Lipids are raised in TB due to mycolipids of mycobacterium.
  • MRS is used for assessing brain tumors, including:
    • Grading of tumors.
    • Monitoring tumor progression versus treatment effects.
    • Diagnosing infectious and metabolic diseases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with progressive memory loss and word-finding difficulty shows language deficits on a neurological exam. The physician orders an MRI to map language centers before treatment. Which MRI technique is most appropriate for this?
questions.explanation:
Functional MRI (fMRI)
  • It is used for noninvasive mapping of brain function related to specific tasks (e.g., motor, language, visual, memory).
  • It provides insights into functional localization, anatomical variations, and the effects of diseases and adaptations and is important for preoperative assessments in tumors, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), and epilepsy surgery.

Principle

Increased neural activity during a task

￬

Localized rise in blood flow for oxygen and glucose supply

￬

￪ Oxygenated hemoglobin (oxyHb)

￬deoxygenated hemoglobin (deoxyHb)

￬

Changes in magnetization

￬

Measured by blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) effect.

 
  • The comparison between the BOLD effect measured at rest and while doing a particular function gives the precise functional localization of nerve cells to be color-mapped.

Applications

  • Detects functionality in diseases like Alzheimer’s.
  • Presurgical assessment for brain tumor and AVM surgeries.
  • Preepilepsy surgery assessment of language centre localization and hemispheric dominance.

Susceptibility- Weighted Imaging (SWI) (Option B)
  • It incorporates T2*-signal intensity losses in images.
  • This is highly sensitive for detecting variations in tissue structure caused by differences in susceptibility.
  • Effectively identifies substances such as
    • Deoxygenated blood
    • Hemosiderin
    • Ferritin
    • Calcium

T2*
  • T2* (T2 star) relaxation is the time taken for the decay of transverse magnetization in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), including both the irreversible T2 relaxation and additional reversible dephasing processes.
  • T2* is always less than T2.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of weakness for an hour on one side of his body. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis but is not compliant with his medications. A CT scan is performed, which shows no acute hemorrhage. An MRI of the brain was performed below. Which MRI sequence is most appropriate for detecting early ischemic changes in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Principle
  • When the patient is placed in an MRI machine, the protons in the body arrange themselves in a specific fashion, that is, parallel or antiparallel to the external magnetic field (B₀).
  • When radiofrequency (FR) waves are passed through the patient, they induce the MR coil/antenna, which is digitally processed into images.
  • The time between each RF pulse is called the repetition time (TR).
  • The time taken between the excitation of protons to the reading of an echo signal is called echo time (TE).

Contraindications

  • Absolute:
    • Cardiac pacemaker
    • Cochlear implants
    • Aneurysmal clips
  • Relative:
    • Claustrophobia
    • Tattoos
    • Recent metal implants & prosthetics
    • Dental implants

T1 weighted MRI (Option A)

T2 weighted MRI (Option C)

  • T1 is the time taken for the longitudinal magnetization to return to 63% of its original value.

Observations:

  • Hyperintense:
    • White matter is more intense than gray matter
    • Fat appears bright
    • Cerebrospinal fluid is of low-intensity
  • Hypointense:
    • Melanin
    • Proteinaceous material
    • Gadolinium-based contrast agents
    • Late subacute hemorrhage

  • T2 is the time taken for the transverse magnetization to decay to 37% of its original value.

Observations:

  • Hyperintense:
    • Cerebrospinal fluid
    • Pathologies involving increased tissue water content
  • Hypointense:
    • White matter is hypointense compared to gray matter
    • Fat
  • It has a short TR and TE
  • It has a long TR and TE 

Newer technologies in MRI

Diffusion-Weighted Imaging (DWI)
  • Any pathology that affects the dispersion of water is detected by this method.
  • The shift of extracellular fluid into the intracellular space causes restricted Brownian motion and gets detected as restricted diffusion in the DWI.
  • The skull is not visualized in this method.
 

Applications:

  • Acute brain infarction:
    • The failure of the sodium-potassium ATP pump leads to cytotoxic edema.
    • Detected within minutes of onset.
  • Ischemia is seen as a bright lesion.
  • Regions of active demyelination.
  • Infections like cerebral abscess.
  • Cellular tumors like glioblastoma and lymphoma.

Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) (Option B)
  • This is useful in identifying:
    • Demyelinating plaques
    • Edema
    • Infarcts after 6 hours
    • Differentiation of arachnoid cyst from other complex cysts
  • Hyperintensity may be seen in cerebral or cerebellar sulci due to:
    • Blood product in subarachnoid hemorrhage
    • Pus in meningitis
    • Leptomeningeal spread of tumor
    • Artefact due to oxygen administration during the scanning.
